content: The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" aims to expand federal investment in Parkinson's research and improve coordination among National Institutes of Health research institutes. It also seeks to enhance care and assistance for individuals with Parkinson's and their family caregivers. The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" amends the Public Health Service Act to focus on Parkinson's disease research. The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" amends the Public Health Service Act to focus on research and training for Parkinson's disease under the Director of NIH, including inter-institute coordination and regular research planning conferences. The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" mandates research planning conferences every 2 years to report to specific committees. The Director of NIH awards Core Center Grants for innovative multidisciplinary research and training. The Director awards Core Center Grants for innovative multidisciplinary research on Parkinson's, with a limit of 10 grants. Each funded center is designated as a Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease. Centers must meet specific qualifications and use the facilities of a single institution or consortium. The Director of the NIH awards Core Center Grants for Parkinson's research to institutions meeting qualifications and conducting basic and clinical research. Centers may also offer training programs and education for scientists and health professionals. The NIH awards Core Center Grants for Parkinson's research to institutions conducting basic and clinical research, offering training programs for scientists and health professionals, and disseminating information to the public. Additionally, they establish a nationwide data system for Parkinson's patients and compare data with general populations. The NIH awards Core Center Grants for Parkinson's research to institutions conducting basic and clinical research, offering training programs for scientists and health professionals, and disseminating information to the public. They also establish a Parkinson's Disease Information Clearinghouse and a national education program to enhance knowledge and understanding of Parkinson's disease. The NIH awards Core Center Grants for Parkinson's research to institutions, supporting training programs for scientists and health professionals. Stipends may be provided for those enrolled in training programs, with support lasting up to five years, extendable by the Director of NIH. The Director of NIH may extend the period of Core Center Grants for Parkinson's research for up to five years based on a review by a peer group. Additionally, the Director will establish a grant program for researchers excelling in Parkinson's research with potential for significant breakthroughs in understanding the disease. Grants for Parkinson's research with potential for breakthroughs in understanding the disease are available for up to 5 years. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998, with additional funding for 1999 and 2000. No funds under this Act can be used for other research. The Act prohibits the use of funds for research involving human fetal tissue obtained from induced abortions, except for tissue from spontaneous abortions or ectopic pregnancies.
